perturbation.original_text: Within 60 days after the death of the Employee, the Employer will provide to the "Insurer" a written statement indicating the amount of each policy's proceeds the Employee's beneficiary is entitled to receive.
perturbation.changed_text: Within 180 days after the death of the Employee, the Employer will provide to the "Insurer" a written statement indicating the amount of each policy's proceeds the Employee's beneficiary is entitled to receive.
perturbation.explanation: Delaying the provision of a written statement to the insurer impacts beneficiary access to death benefits. Extended delays in claim processing and benefit distribution can violate Pennsylvania's Unfair Insurance Practices Act.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Pennsylvania's Unfair Insurance Practices Act addresses delays in claim processing and benefit distribution.

perturbation.original_text:
(3) Review Procedure. A Claimant or his authorized representative may with respect to any denied claim:
(a) Request a review upon written application filed within 60 days after receipt by the Claimant of notice of the denial of his claim;
perturbation.changed_text:
(3) Review Procedure. A Claimant or his authorized representative may with respect to any denied claim:
(a) Request a review upon written application filed within 30 days after receipt by the Claimant of notice of the denial of his claim;
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the claim review request period impacts the claimant's rights. Pennsylvania law, guided by ERISA standards, generally allows a reasonable timeframe (often exceeding 60 days) for appealing denied claims to safeguard beneficiaries.
perturbation.contradicted_law: ERISA and related Pennsylvania regulations ensure reasonable appeal timeframes to protect claimants.

perturbation.original_text: (4) Decision on Review. The Named Fiduciary (or its designee) will render a decision upon review of a denied claim within 60 days after receipt of a request for review. If special circumstances warrant additional time, the decision will be rendered as soon as possible, but not later than 120 days after receipt of request for review.
perturbation.changed_text: (4) Decision on Review. The Named Fiduciary (or its designee) will render a decision upon review of a denied claim within 150 days after receipt of a request for review. If special circumstances warrant additional time, the decision will be rendered as soon as possible, but not later than 240 days after receipt of request for review.
perturbation.explanation: Increasing the review period significantly delays resolution, violating Pennsylvania's statutes on prompt insurance claim handling. Lengthy review periods can violate good faith and fair dealing principles.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Pennsylvania statutes on prompt insurance claim handling and principles of good faith and fair dealing.
